question: During the succession events in the city, whom did the people lead to the market-place, resulting in an encounter with the new king?
gold_answer: The people led the princess to the market-place.
llm_answer: The people led a beautiful princess to the market-place, where the new king was sitting in royal state.

context.text: back door, and ran away out into the wide world. She wandered for many days, over mountain and moor, through fen and through forest, until she came to a fair city. Here all the bells were ringing, and the people shouting and flinging caps into the air; for their old king was dead, and they were just about to crown a new one. The new king was a stranger, who had come to the town only the day before; but as soon as he heard of the old monarch's death, he told the people that he was a king himself, and as he happened to be without a kingdom at that moment, he would be quite willing to rule over them. The people joyfully assented, for the late king had left no heir; and now all the preparations had been completed. The crown had been polished up, and a new tip put on the sceptre, as the old king had quite spoiled it by poking the fire with it for upwards of forty years. When the people saw the beautiful princess, they welcomed her with many bows, and insisted on leading her before the new king. "Who knows but that they may be related?" said everybody. "They both came from the same direction, and both are strangers." Accordingly the princess was led to the market-place, where the king was sitting in royal state. He had a fat, red, shining face, and did not look like the kings whom she had been in the habit of seeing;

at once. "Ah!" he said, "I am all right when we come to forward and back. Tum-tiddy tum-tum, tum-tum-tum!" and he pranced forward, put out one foot, and slid back again, with an air of enjoyment that was pleasant to behold. "That's right!" said the master, approvingly. "Stand a little straighter, Bruin! Cracker, you don't point your toe enough. Hold your head up, <DW53>, and don't be looking round at your tail every minute. _Tum_-tiddy tum-tum, _tum_-tum-tum! _tiddy_-iddy tum-tum, _tum_-tum-tum! Balance to partners! Here, Bruin! you can balance to me. Turn partners, and back to places! There, now you may rest a moment before you begin on the waltz step." "Ah! that is _my_ delight," said the squirrel. "What a sensation we shall make at the wedding! One of the woodmouse's daughters is very pretty, with such a nice little nose, and such bright eyes! I shall ask her to waltz with me." "There won't be any one of my size there, I suppose," said the raccoon. "You and I will have to be partners, Toto." "And I must stay at home and waltz alone!"

The Pioneer Guards, the oldest military company in the state, had the right of line. They had just received their Minie rifles and bayonets, and, with the drum-major

royal state. He had a fat, red, shining face, and did not look like the kings whom she had been in the habit of seeing; but nevertheless the princess made a graceful courtesy, and then waited to hear what he would say. The new king seemed rather embarrassed when he saw that it was a princess who appeared before him; but he smiled graciously, and said, in a smooth oily voice,-- "I trust your 'Ighness is quite well. And 'ow did yer 'Ighness leave yer pa and ma?" At these words the princess raised her head and looked fixedly at the red-faced king; then she replied, with scornful distinctness,-- "What is the price of butter?" At these words an alarming change came over the king's face. The red faded from it, and left it a livid green; his teeth chattered; his eyes stared, and rolled in their sockets; while the sceptre dropped from his trembling hand and fell at the princess's feet. For the truth was, this was no king at all, but a retired butterman, who had laid by a little money at his trade, and had thought of setting up a public house; but chancing to pass through this city at the very time when they were looking for a king, it struck him that he might just as well fill the vacant place as any one else. No one had thought of his being an impostor; but when the princess fixed

the raccoon. "You and I will have to be partners, Toto." "And I must stay at home and waltz alone!" said Bruin, goodnaturedly. "It is a misfortune, in some ways, to be so big." "But great good fortune in others, Bruin, dear!" said Pigeon Pretty, affectionately. "I, for one, would not have you smaller, for the world!" "Nor would I!" said the grandmother, heartily. "Bruin, my friend and protector, your size and strength are the greatest possible comfort to me, coupled as they are with a kind heart and a willing--" "Paw!" cried Toto. "Your sentiments are most correct, Granny, dear; but Bruin _must_ not stand bowing in the middle of the room, even if he is grateful. Go in the corner, Bruin, and practise your steps, while I take a turn with <DW53>. And you, Cracker, can--" But Master Cracker did not wait for instructions. He had been watching the parrot for some minutes, with his head on one side and his eyes twinkling with merriment; and now, springing suddenly upon her perch, he caught the astonished bird round the body, leaped with her to the floor, and began to whirl her round the room at a surprising rate, in tolerably good time to the lively

bonds of Minnesota were a blot on the pages of her otherwise spotless record. Nearly 250 miles of road were graded, on which the state foreclosed and a few years later donated the same to new organizations. During the administration of Gov. Pillsbury the state compromised with the holders of these securities and paid 50 per cent of their nominal value. Will she ever pay the rest? In the latter part of May, 1858, a battle was fought near Shakopee between the Sioux and the Chippewas. A party of Chippewa warriors, under the command of the famous Chief Hole-in-the-day, surprised a body of Sioux on the river bottoms near Shakopee and mercilessly opened fire on them, killing and wounding fifteen or twenty. Eight or ten Chippewas were killed during the engagement. The daily papers sent reporters to the scene of the conflict and they remained in that vicinity several days on the lookout for further engagements. Among the reporters was John W. Sickels, a fresh young man from one of the Eastern cities. He was attached to the Times' editorial staff and furnished that paper with a very graphic description of the events of the preceding days, and closed his report by saying that he was unable to find out the "origin of the difficulty." As the Sioux and Chippewas were hereditary enemies, his closing announcement afforded considerable amusement to the old inhabitants. The celebration in St. Paul in honor of the successful laying of

to be the owner of a fleet horse--to own a fine horse and saddle was ever the pride and ambition of the young Kentuckian--and he won many bottles; but the end proved that it was bad instead of good luck, for Tom subsequently became too fond of the bottle. Tom was young and hopeful, far away from his kindred, and he also married the daughter of an Englishman, who was not so fortunate as to be the owner of any portion of the virgin soil, but distinguished himself as a fine gardener, and all the inheritance Tom received with his wife was a _cart-load of gourds_. You laugh, but you must remember that a few pewter plates and cob-handle knives was all that adorned the cupboards of some of our fathers, and gourds of different size made useful vessels. Coffee was not much in use, and in the dawn of the Revolution a party of brave Americans had thrown a ship-load of tea into the sea. Tom, like many of the young planters, built a cabin upon a tract of land, under the Henderson claim, as purchased from the Cherokee Indians, which claim was subsequently set aside by the State of Virginia. Tom, as we have said, was of a restless disposition, and from a planter he turned to be a boatman. Leaving his family at home in their cabin, he engaged to make a trip to Fort Washington (Cincinnati, then a village) on a

The doctor took the paper and rushed out into the street waving the paper frantically in the air, cursing the president at every step. From 1854, the date of the starting of the three St. Paul daily papers, until 1860, the time of the completion of the Winslow telegraph line, there was great strife between the Pioneer, Minnesotian and Times as to which would be the first to appear on the street with the full text of the president's message. The messages of Pierce and Buchanan were very lengthy, and for several days preceding their arrival the various offices had all the type of every description distributed and all the printers who could possibly be procured engaged to help out on the extra containing the forthcoming message. It was customary to pay every one employed, from the devil to the foreman, $2.50 in gold, and every printer in the city was notified to be in readiness for the approaching typographical struggle. One year one of the proprietors of the Minnesotian thought he would surprise the other offices, and he procured the fastest livery team In the city and went down the river as far as Red Wing to intercept the mail coach, and expected to return to St. Paul three or four hours in advance of the regular mail, which would give him that much advantage over his competitors. Owing to some miscalculation as to the time the stage left Chicago the message was delivered in St. Paul twenty-four hours

first steamer, Aug. 11, 1866. The new steamer was lodged with Hope Engine company, and an engineer and fireman appointed at a salary of $1,600 per year for the two. The boys of Hope Engine company did not like the selection of the engineer of the new steamer and took the matter so seriously that their organization was disbanded and St. Paul Hose Company No. 1 was organized, and they took charge of the new steamer. The rapid growth of the city necessitated the frequent purchase of new fire apparatus, and at the present time the St. Paul fire department has 211 paid men, 15 steamers, 4 chemicals, 8 hook and ladder companies and 122 horses. The volunteer fire department had no better friend than the late Mrs. Bartlett Presley. She was the guardian angel of the fire department. No night so cold or storm so great that Mrs. Presley was not present and with her own hands provide coffee and sandwiches for the tired and hungry firemen who had been heroically battling with the flames. She was an honored guest at all entertainments with which the firemen were connected, and was always toasted and feasted by the boys at the brakes. She will ever be remembered, not only by the firemen, but by all old settlers, as one of the many noble women in St. Paul whose unostentatious deeds of charity have caused a ray of sunshine in many

he might just as well fill the vacant place as any one else. No one had thought of his being an impostor; but when the princess fixed her clear eyes on him and asked him that familiar question, which he had been in the habit of hearing many times a day for a great part of his life, the guilty butterman thought himself detected, and shook in his guilty shoes. Hastily descending from his throne, he beckoned he princess into a side-chamber, and closing the door, besought her in moving terms not to betray him. "Here," he said, "is a bag of rubies as big as pigeon's eggs. There are six thousand of them, and I 'umbly beg your 'Ighness to haccept them as a slight token hof my hesteem, if your 'Ighness will kindly consent to spare a respeckable tradesman the disgrace of being hexposed." The princess reflected, and came to the conclusion that, after all, a butterman might make as good a king as any one else; so she took the rubies with a gracious little nod, and departed, while all the people shouted, "Hooray!" and followed her, waving their hats and kerchiefs, to the gates of the city. With her bag of rubies over her shoulder, the fair princess now pursued her journey, and fared forward over heath and hill, through brake and through brier. After several days

communities.summary:
1. **Title**: St. Paul Hotel Fires
2. **Summary**: The city of St. Paul experienced a series of devastating hotel fires during its early history, resulting in significant losses and damage. Notable hotels that were destroyed by fire include the Daniels house, Sintominie hotel, Rice house, New England, Empire saloon, and Winslow house. These fires often occurred due to lack of fire protection and were exacerbated by strong winds. The city's fire department, despite being understaffed and underequipped, worked tirelessly to combat the blazes and save lives. The fires led to changes in the city's fire safety measures and the development of a more robust fire department.
3. **Keywords**: St. Paul, Hotel Fires, Fire Department, Historic Disasters, 19th Century

1. **Title**: Historical Events in St. Paul
2. **Summary**: The text chunks describe various historical events that took place in St. Paul, including the celebration of the successful laying of the first Atlantic cable, the "Five Million Loan Election", and the early days of steamboating on the Mississippi River. The city's growth and development are highlighted through the establishment of new businesses, hotels, and transportation systems. The chunks also mention notable figures, such as Cyrus W. Field and Gov. Sibley, who played important roles in shaping the city's history. The events are often described in detail, with attention to the social and cultural context of the time.
3. **Keywords**: St. Paul, Atlantic Cable, Steamboating, Minnesota History, 19th Century

1. **Historic St. Paul Events**
2. **Summary**: The text chunks discuss various historic events that occurred in St. Paul, including a hotel fire at the International Hotel in 1869, the death of Captain Acker during the Civil War, and the assassination of President Lincoln. The city's history, notable figures, and significant events are highlighted, showcasing the city's growth and development. The International Hotel fire resulted in significant losses but no lives were lost due to the quick thinking of the night watchman. Captain Acker was a respected figure in St. Paul, and his death was met with widespread mourning. The city also played a significant role in the Civil War, with many of its citizens participating in the conflict.
3. **Keywords**: St. Paul, Historic Events, International Hotel, Captain Acker, President Lincoln

1. **Title**: Travels in Cornwall
2. **Summary**: The text chunks describe the travels of a group of people in Cornwall, England, during the late 19th century. They visit various locations, including the Lizard, and meet new people, such as Charles, their charioteer, and a kindly Cornishman who welcomes them into his home. The narrative is filled with vivid descriptions of the natural beauty of Cornwall, including the sea, gardens, and autumnal landscapes. The group also engages in social interactions, including tea parties and conversations with the locals. The text has a leisurely and nostalgic tone, reflecting on the joys of travel and the warmth of human connections.
3. **Keywords**: Cornwall, Travel, Nature, Social Interactions, Nostalgia

1. **Title**: Whimsical Woodland Creatures
2. **Summary**: The text chunks describe a group of woodland creatures, including a bear, squirrel, raccoon, and parrot, as they engage in various activities such as dancing, playing music, and socializing. The scenes are filled with lighthearted and humorous moments, showcasing the unique personalities of each character. The narrative also touches on the theme of identity and belonging, as the creatures navigate their relationships with one another and their place in the world. Meanwhile, a separate storyline involves a princess who escapes her royal life and encounters a group of robbers and a false king, highlighting her wit and independence.
3. **Keywords**: Woodland creatures, Dancing, Socialization, Identity, Princess, Adventure

1. **Title**: Exploring Cornwall's Landscapes
2. **Summary**: The text chunks describe the author's journey through Cornwall, visiting various locations such as Tintagel, the Lizard, and Camelford. The author reflects on the region's natural beauty, its rich history, and the legend of King Arthur. The narrative also touches on the local culture, the people, and their way of life. The author's experiences are woven together with descriptions of the landscape, historical references, and personal anecdotes. The text conveys a sense of wonder, curiosity, and appreciation for the region's unique character. The author's encounters with the locals, their customs, and traditions are also highlighted, showcasing the warmth and hospitality of the Cornish people.
3. **Keywords**: Cornwall, King Arthur, Tintagel, Landscape, Local Culture

1. **Title**: Early St. Paul Fire Department
2. **Summary**: The early St. Paul fire department was formed with the organization of the Pioneer Hook and Ladder company, followed by the establishment of other companies such as Hope Engine Company No. 1 and Minnehaha Engine Company No. 2. These companies played a crucial role in protecting the city from fires, with their members being exempt from certain civic duties as compensation for their services. The fire department's annual parade became a significant event in the city, and the companies worked together to respond to fires and protect the community. The city's fire department was also influenced by national events, such as the Civil War, with many St. Paul residents participating in the war effort. The fire department's history is closely tied to the development of the city, with many prominent business leaders and citizens involved in its formation and operation.
3. **Keywords**: St. Paul, Fire Department, Pioneer Hook and Ladder, Hope Engine Company, Minnehaha Engine Company

1. **Title**: Historical American Frontier
2. **Summary**: The given text chunks appear to be excerpts from a historical novel or narrative about the American frontier, specifically focusing on the regions of Kentucky, Arkansas, and the Mississippi River. The stories touch on themes of conflict, settlement, and daily life in the early days of American history, including interactions with Native American tribes, steam navigation, and the establishment of wood yards. The narrative also explores the characters and experiences of individuals living in these areas, such as Tom Fairfield, Don and Dan Carlo, and others. The text weaves together elements of history, adventure, and social commentary, providing a glimpse into the lives of people in the American frontier during the 18th and 19th centuries.
3. **Keywords**: American Frontier, Kentucky, Mississippi River, Steam Navigation, Settlement

1. **Title**: Life in 19th Century Kentucky
2. **Summary**: The text chunks describe life in 19th century Kentucky, focusing on the experiences of characters such as Tom Fairfield, Don Carlo, and Aunt Katy. The stories touch on themes of family, religion, and social class, providing a glimpse into the daily lives and struggles of people living in Kentucky during this time period. The characters face various challenges, including poverty, illness, and personal struggles, but also find joy and community in their relationships and faith. The text also mentions historical events and cultural practices, such as the "jerks" phenomenon in church services and the importance of navigation on the Ohio river.
3. **Keywords**: Kentucky, 19th century, family, religion, social class

1. **Title**: Life in Canada City
2. **Summary**: The text chunks describe life in Canada City, a mining town, focusing on the experiences of its young women, particularly Cissy Trixit, the daughter of a prominent banker. The community is portrayed as vibrant, with social interactions and relationships between characters like Cissy, her friend Piney, and various men, including the Reverend Mr. Windibrook and a young engineer. The narrative touches on themes of beauty, social status, and the complexities of human connections in a small, close-knit community. The stories also mention the town's layout, its church, and the contrast between the natural beauty of the surrounding landscape and the harsh realities of mining life.
3. **Keywords**: Canada City, Mining Town, Social Interactions, Cissy Trixit, Community Life

1. **Title**: Social Commentary in England
2. **Summary**: The text chunks discuss various aspects of English society, including the behaviors of individuals like Hinze and Ganymede, who are portrayed as exemplifying certain social traits. The narrative also touches on the changing times in England, comparing the past to the present, and noting the country's ability to balance stability with susceptibility to change. The author reflects on their own experiences and observations of English life, from their father's stories of the past to their current experiences in London. The text also explores themes of youth, age, and the perception of these qualities in society. Overall, the chunks provide a commentary on the social landscape of England, highlighting both the consistencies and changes that have occurred over time.
3. **Keywords**: English Society, Social Commentary, Personal Reflections, Change and Stability, Youth and Age

1. **Title**: 19th Century American Life
2. **Summary**: The provided text chunks describe various aspects of 19th century American life, including the experiences of women, the impact of the Civil War, and the struggles of individuals pursuing education and careers. The writings touch on themes of social justice, personal freedom, and the pursuit of knowledge. The authors express strong opinions on issues like slavery and women's rights, showcasing the tumultuous nature of the time period. The texts also provide glimpses into the daily lives of individuals, including their relationships, occupations, and personal struggles.
3. **Keywords**: 19th Century America, Civil War, Women's Rights, Education, Social Justice
